definition: lit. proper behavior is based on reciprocity (idiom)/fig. to return politeness for politeness
gift/rite/ceremony/CL:份[fen4]/propriety/etiquette/courtesy
surname Li/abbr. for 禮記|礼记[Li3 ji4], Classic of Rites
still/yet/to value/to esteem
surname Shang
old variant of 往[wang3]
to go (in a direction)/to/towards/(of a train) bound for/past/previous
to come/to arrive/to come round/ever since/next

sentences.english: The Chinese nation has always been ceremonies, reciprocity has become habit.
sentences.chinese: 中华民族素来是礼仪之邦，礼尚往来早已成为习惯。

sentences.english: "Exchanges, " we read: "Send us two copies of your publication and we will recropriate.
sentences.chinese: 请寄两份你们的刊物给我们，我们一定礼尚往来。

sentences.english: Courtesy calls for reciprocity, is China's tradition.
sentences.chinese: 礼尚往来，是中华民族的传统。

sentences.english: Courtesy on one side only lasts not long.
sentences.chinese: 单方面的礼貌不会持久，礼尚往来。

definition: not to reciprocate is against etiquette (classical)/to respond in kind
pinyin: lai2 er2 bu4 wang3 fei1 li3 ye3

definition: nobody will find fault with extra courtesy (idiom)/courtesy costs nothing
toss a peach, get back a plum (idiom); to return a favor/to exchange gifts/Scratch my back, and I'll scratch yours.
to return an invitation
to give a present
gift given to sb when meeting them for the first time
Don't get a reward if it's not deserved. (idiom)
goose feather sent from afar, a trifling present with a weighty thought behind it (idiom); It's not the gift that counts, but the thought behind it.
human emotions/social relationship/friendship/favor/a good turn
to give a dinner party/to entertain guests/to invite to dinner
slight present but weighty meaning (idiom); It's not the present the counts, it's the thought behind it.
a gentleman's friendship, insipid as water (idiom, from Zhuangzi 莊子|庄子[Zhuang1 zi3])
pinyin: jun1 zi3 zhi1 jiao1 dan4 ru2 shui3

definition: lit. presenting the Buddha with borrowed flowers (idiom); fig. to win favor or influence using sb else's property/plagiarism
peaceful measures before using force (idiom); diplomacy before violence/jaw-jaw is better than war-war
to modestly decline
honorarium/gift as thanks
